subject: How should protected inherited method be tested?
msgSnippet: I read the article via the FAQ s about how to test protected/private methods with JUnit, and it works fine for non-inherited methods. But how should i test
messageBody:
I read the article via the FAQ's about how to test protected/private
methods with JUnit, and it works fine for non-inherited methods.

But how should i test protected inherited methods? The methods should
initially be tested in the parent class, but sometimes the inherited
methods are needed to verify tests on the inherited class, e.g. a
get-method.

For example:
class A{
protected int no = 1;

protected changeNo(){
no = 2;
}

protected getNo{
return no;
}
}

class B entends A{
protected changeNo(){
no = 3;
}
}

When testing changeNo in class B, I would like to verify that no == 3,
but I cannot access no or A.getNo since they are not returned in
object.getClass().getDeclaredFields() or
object.getClass().getDeclaredMethods() when called on class B.

I could put all my tests in the same package as the classes being
tested, but I would like to avoid that.

- Louise
